Interaction.name: Simulated Situation with Text and Image
Interaction.node: Select Next to continue.

Liquidity Ratios

Liquidity measures the adequacy of an organization's working capital (current assets) to meet the current obligations. In other words, does an organization have enough cash or other current assets that can be quickly turned into cash?

Current ratio

The current ratio focuses on the current assets that are available to honor the current liabilities that are incurred as a result of normal operations. The current ratio is a relative comparison of current assets to current liabilities. It calculates the number of dollars of current assets that are available to cover each dollar of current liabilities.

Current Ratio = Current Assets/Current Liabilities

The accounts receivable turnover ratio

The accounts receivable turnover ratio measures the quality and liquidity of the accounts receivable.

Accounts Receivable Turnover = Net Credit Sales/Average Accounts Receivable

The quality of the receivables is defined as collection without losses. It is assumed that the longer the receivables are outstanding, the less likely that they will be collected. The turnover is an indicator of the age of the receivables. It indicates how many times, on average, the receivables revolve (how many times they are generated and collected during the year). The credit terms should determine an expected turnover rate. For example, if the credit terms are net 60, it would be expected that the turnover would be six times if receivables were actually collected within the 60 days. A low actual ratio in comparison to the expected ratio may indicate the possibility of collection problems.

The working capital turnover ratio

The working capital turnover ratio measures the sales created through the use of net working capital. Cash and accounts payable are used to purchase inventory that is then sold. Other current assets and current liabilities are used or incurred to support operations necessary to create sales

Working Capital Turnover = Sales/Net Working Capital

In other words, this ratio measures how effectively management uses current funds to create sales. A higher ratio in comparison to net working capital is preferred.

Inventory turnover ratio

The inventory turnover ratio measures the speed with which inventory can be converted into sales. In other words, the control that management has over inventory is assessed. The quality of the inventory is determined by the company's ability to use and dispose of inventory without a loss.

Inventory Turnover Ratio = Cost of Goods Sold/Average Inventory
